characters: "TIL IT'S TIME FOR HER COMING OUT...
MUSIC COME UP AND CARRIES ACROSS
THE LITTLE GIRL SHE JUST WANDERS
I SAID ROUND AND ROUND AND ROUND,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man is walking along the tracks. A slow, aimless walk. Lost and lonely. A setting sun at his back. He's handsome in a rugged, dangerous way. Denim and leather. A great sadness and confusion on his face. His name is KEITH NELSON. DRUMS OBLITERATE THE STRINGS, and we RETURN TO BLACK and TITLES BEGIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's playing drums to the TRACK. Hard, serious. With great purpose and need. She's boyish and tough. Her prettiness is intentionally buried beneath acres of atti- tude. This is WATTS. DRUMMER GIRL. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: BOY AND GIRL
dialogues.text: Beautiful girl, handsome boy. Perfection meets perfection Making-out against the yellow slatted light of a darkened bedroom. She's AMANDA JONES. He's HARDY JENNS. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freight train is thundering down the tracks. A HORN BLA The speeding bulk dominates the FRAME. The SOUND of DIESE ENGINES and CHATTERING TRACK obliterates the MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy we saw before, Keith Nelson, continues down the t He looks up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is bearing down on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEHIND Keith TO SEE that he's walking into the approachin train. The HORN BLASTS AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Watching the train. No reaction. A collision with the tra will only give him what he wants. Change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train shudders and rocks on the track. The HORN BLAST AND HOLDS.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Still no change in expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM BEHIND Keith. The train FILLS THE FRAME. It's nearly on him. He steps out off the tracks at the last moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith heads down the embankment as the train hurtles past No change in expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The homes of working people. Squat bungalows, clean but modest. A black Corvette is parked in the driveway of one of the houses. It stands out among the more utilitarian vehicles on the street. An incongruent luxury. A front door opens, and the boy and the girl we saw making-out in the TITLE SEQUENCE step out of the house. Her blouse is untucked, her hair's mussed, stocking feet. She's flushed and floating. He's in a hurry. Done with her, on to other things. She holds him back and kisses him. There's no tenderness on his part. It's one-sided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith is across the street, leaning on a lamp post. His gritty hands wrapped around the pole. Washed but never clean. A hint of anger, a touch of resentment. Hardy doesn't belong in the neighborhood. Certainly doesn't de- serve the girl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy gets in his car, fires the engine and backs out of the driveway. Amanda waves goodbye from the porch. Hardy drops the Corvette in gear and squeals away. An irresis- table show of disrespect for the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: There's something tragic about his look. Hardy has every- thing money can buy and is now stealing the things it can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda goes back in the house.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: His observation was careful and considered. He looks at his greasy hands. Too dirty to touch her. He pushes off the pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tired two story in a modest neighborhood. Clean but sim Maybe a little nicer than Amanda's neighborhood. But not much. Keith cuts across the freshly mown lawn, up the dri way and around the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's mother, CAROL, is at a small built-in desk beneat a wall phone balancing her checkbook. She's wearing nurse whites. She works. Dinner is on the fire. A ten-year-old girl, CINDY, is sitting at the kitchen table. She's cata- loguing her Garbage Pail kids in a photo album. Keith com in the back door. Cindy strikes.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: It's Semi-Conscious Keith. Keith ignores her and continues through the kitchen. Caro addresses him without looking up.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hi, honey. How was work? He exits into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You still haven't told me when you're going to cut your hair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Mom? You're flapping your lips in vain. Keith vacated. Carol addresses Cindy without looking up.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Speak English, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith crosses out of the dining into the foyer. His fathe calls to him from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Keith? Is that you? Keith stops at the bottom of the stairs. He sighs. Caught He swings around and steps into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's father, CLIFF, is sitting on the couch. Spread ou before him are university brochures.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He looks at Cliff and the brochures. He's suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: He speaks without looking at Keith.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I've been checking out colleges... He looks up at Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Plays it flat.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Aren't you a little too old for college? A thin smile breaks through.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: An incredulous stare. Incredulous that Keith can be so cavalier about a subject that Cliff considers vital, pres ing and overwhelmingly serious. There's no humor to his retort. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: If I'd gone to college, I wouldn't be selling tires six days a week.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He doesn't like hearing Cliff run himself down.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: A word of warning.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: If you don't get with the program, you'll be selling tires, too. (pause; lightens- up) You want to take a minute and look at these brochures? A whole bunch of new ones came in the mail today. (sorts through stack, finds one, holds it up) Take a look. Some of these are real nice. Look at this, coed physical education.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: The last thing he wants to do.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Can I do it later?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: He's been put off before.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to break your back, I just want you to get off the dime and think about your future.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He nods. He's heard it before.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: One last thought. What's really at the heart of the colle issue. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You got a shot to be the first guy in this family who didn't have to wash his hands after a day's work.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He knows. All too well. He shows his hands to Cliff. Dirty. Motor dirt. Like Cliff said. He pushes off the door arch and heads back into the foyer. He heads up the stairs, side-stepping the debris piled on the stairs to be carried up at anyone's convenience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith opens the door and stops cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's sister, LAURA, is sitting on the floor going thro his records. LP's are out of their sleeves. She's rudely holding an LP, looking at the label. Keith's room is a shrine to art. It's a serious shelter from the outside world. One wall is covered, every inch, with reproduction posters, art show posters, art postcard reproductions torn from books and magazines. A collage of the history of art. A second wall is devoted to his own sketches. A third wall is a trompe l'oeil of an endless marble gallery. The fourth wall is hung with his own can- vases. A stereo carefully put together out of discarded pieces and parts. His bed is a mattress on the floor. A chair direct from the dump. A rug from off a curb during spring trash pick-up day. A desk made of an old door held up by two oil drums. The surface is covered with sketches and india ink pens and brushes, ink bottles. Clay and pla ter models and studies. Everywhere are found objects, things intended for future pieces and studies. It is an artist's studio in a boy's bedroom. There's no question from his surroundings that he's serious about his talent.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm looking for that song about the guy that killed himself for the girl that hated his guts. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's furious at the intrusion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Disregards his anger.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do you know which song I'm talking about? Keith takes the LP from Laura.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Do you understand the concept of privacy?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. That's why I don't let anyone in my room.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Get out of here before I throw your ass out the window.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (outraged) God, are you in a bad mood!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Is this a side effect of being massively unliked or...? Keith grabs Laura by the arm, rips her to her feet, walks her to the door and shoves her out.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She's enraged.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: If I get a black and blue mark you monger, you're dead! The door slams on her. She screams at the top of her voic

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family are eating dinner. Laura is showing her upper arm to Carol.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Look at it. You see what he did to me? Carol looks.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Then you need glasses. If I wanted to sit out, I couldn't wear a bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Exposing your skin to sunlight will make you old before your time.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: (to Laura) You stay out of his room. (to Keith) You got a problem with her, see me before you rough her up.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What right does she have to break into my room? And I didn't rough her up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I have practically no feeling left in the upper part of my arm.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Drop it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I wish just once you guys could experience the humiliation of having the weirdest guy ina huge school be a blood relative.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Your father said, drop it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: This whole family revolves around Keith. I'm sick of it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Keith sets down his fork and napkin.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That's not true and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (to Carol) I'll be upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You haven't finished your dinner.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Keith gets up and exists. Cliff calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: What about these colleges, Keith? (pause) I expect an answer.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do you know what a total waste of money it's going to be letting him go to college? He'll have this expensive education that he'll never use because all he wants to do is make incredibly ugly art that won't ever look good in anybody's house. Cliff, Carol and Cindy stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Am I wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC'S PLAYING. He's sitting at his desk looking at a tattered photo.

dialogues.speaker: PICTURE
dialogues.text: A candid snapshot. Of a girl looking back over her shoul- der. A caught expression on her face. A beautiful girl. The girl we saw in the opening.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Dips his brush in ink and applies it to paper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAPER
dialogues.text: A steady hand draws the sweep of a girl's neck and shoul- der. Another produces a fine, strong jawline.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: A hint of a smile as he looks at his first strokes. The SOURCE MUSIC PLAYING in the room is lost to a DRUM TRACK PLAYED AS SCORE. The DRUMS CONTINUE ACROSS the:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, traditional high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battered, wasted Mini with English drive whips into the parking lot and flies into a parking spot narrowly missin the shiny new imports on either side of the vacant spot. DRUMS OUT ON A CYMBAL SPLASH.

dialogues.speaker: GROUND
dialogues.text: The car door opens and a black patent-leather tie shoe, covered with metal studs steps out of the car. We MOVE UP FROM the shoes, PAST worn, torn jeans, a tank top, black man's brocade vest, drum sticks shoved in a black leather belt, red kid gloves and a cheap digital watch on a metal stretch band shoved halfway up the arm to the girl we saw in the opening. She's Watts, Drummer Girl. Big breathless smile enjoying the rush of a near miss, the affirmation o life that comes from a challenge to it. She takes off her tiny red sunglasses and looks in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you aware of how close that was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith looks up at her. He's annoyed with her driving. The answer to her question is on his face. He can't help but smile at her exhilaration. He picks up his books off the seat and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith gets out of the car. He has to squeeze out. Drummer Girl's parked a bit close on his side. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Imagine what I can do when I get my driver's license back. She gives him a big smile and twirls her drumsticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy Jenns and a couple of his friends are hanging in th parking lot. Leaning against a tricked-out Toyota truck. MUSIC's coming from inside the truck. Hardy's bending the radio antenna over. With his free hand, he's holding the owner of the car away. His intention isn't to do damage, only to harass his friend. The game is interrupted as something catches Hardy's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl and Keith heading into school.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY AND HIS FRIENDS
dialogues.text: Hardy lets the antenna go. He points out Keith and Drumme Girl. Big derisive smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl and Keith head across the lot to the school. They're unaware that they're being observed. She's fiddl- ing with her drumsticks as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You don't have any books?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Not on me.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You never study, do you?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Not school stuff. My urge is to make music. Tell me how reading "Lord Of The Flies' '1l make me a better drummer.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You have no desire to get out of this place?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You're talking to someone who was raised on cocktail onions and cigarette butts. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like nothing better. I have two feet. I'll get out. I'm not worried. You must be getting heat from the old man about college again.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's all he thinks about.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: In comparative terms, it's probably better to have an old man nagging you about the future than to have no old man not nagging you about anything.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Things not too great at home?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: The same. The reach for the school doors. There's a crowd. Drummer Girl taps out a little riff on the back pack of a kid standing in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. As long as you stand by me, I'm covered.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Where would I be without you?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Seeing as how I drive you to school every day, you'd probably be sitting on your front porch. The kid Drummer Girl is tapping on turns around. He's an angry little freshman dead head. His name is Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Very much so. Drummer Girl twirls her stick and gives the kid a pop on the top of his head. She steps in front of him and opens the door for Keith.  27 28 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith and Drummer Girl continue down a crowded hallway. It's a corridor claimed by the headbangers. The angry flotsam of the school loiters on the window ledges, lis- tening to MUSIC, laying comatose, talking loudly, verball abusing anyone and everyone that passes. Including Keith. His dark clothes, blank expression and boots make him ap- pear at home in the corridor. But he's not immune to at- tack.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey! Paint my picture!

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (to Keith) Some day when your shit's hanging in a museum and these guys are OD'd you'll be laughing.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm laughing now.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I think it's hip that you paint. I think it's hip that I drum. And it's perfect that we're friends. Keith stops. Drummer Girl stops. He looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A leg is stuck out, across his path. We MOVE UP TO a big, ugly-looking SKINHEAD. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He stares at the kid. Doesn't give up anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith steps over the obstruction. The Skinhead pulls his leg in as Keith raises his leg and makes him highstep ove nothing. A laugh. Keith stares at the Skinhead.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: That's real original. How long you been pulling that one?

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: (unfazed) How long have you been a lesbian? Drummer Girl's face goes ashen. Keith's face tightens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: You're carrying too much up front to be a guy. So you must be a... Keith grabs Skinhead by his jacket front and pulls him to his feet. He realizes that he's grabbed more than he anticipated. Skinhead towers over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MALE TEACHER rudely shoves his way through the crowd. He's assigned the security. Shirt-sleeves and tie and two way radio on his belt.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: That's enough! He grabs Keith's shoulder and pushes him aside.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Clear out! Keith backs away.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Now! He turns and heads down the hall. Drummer Girl points her drumstick at Skinhead.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Wimp. She follows after Keith. The teacher turns to Skinhead.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything! He jumped on me! Why don't you nail him? The teacher flips a pack of Marlboro's out of Skinhead's shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: It's not my shirt. He reaches around behind and yanks a half pint out of his hip pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: That's just for show. He reaches in the other pocket and takes out a packet of scene playing cards. The teacher looks at them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Those were a gift. He tries his most charming smile.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: You just got detention, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's slumped down in a chair in the back of the librar He's working in a sketchpad. He's got his eye on somethin Drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl we saw in the opening and in the photograph, Ama Jones, is across the room and forward of Keith. A boy is sitting at her table. His back is to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's obviously very taken with her. Watching her every move. He feels eyes upon him. An uneasiness comes over him. His eyes shift quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP ON HARDY
dialogues.text: Hardy's turned in his seat, looking directly at Keith. He's not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's caught. He looks down to avoid the stare. A beat and he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that Hardy was the boy with his back to Keith. He's turned around in his seat. Amanda looks from Hardy to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Tries to convince himself that he's not intimidated. Look away. Another beat and he returns his look to Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: He's still staring at Keith. He points to Keith, holds up a pencil, points to Amanda, points to his neck, points to Keith, points to the pencil, turns it straight up and sna it in half. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crusty, older woman looks up with a scowl and lets out a loud, shhh!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Looks at Hardy to let him know that he doesn't scare that easily.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She looks from Hardy to Keith. Wondering what Keith is doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith is walking down the hallway. Drummer Girl pushes her way through the crowd to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Keith! He stops. She's flustered and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you sitting down?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No. I'm standing in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Right. I have some bad news.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: This is unconfirmed but I have it from a reliable source.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I think your father's at school.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: How do you know it's my father?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You know those hats he wears?

dialogues.speaker: HAT
dialogues.text: A straw panama is resting on a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff has taken half an hour off work to visit Keith's counselor, a gaunt man in his fifties, MR. GALE.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: So there's nothing special we need to know about filling out the applications?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GALE
dialogues.text: Just what we've covered.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be a pain in the butt about this, I just want to double-check. You know kids they wait until the last minute on everything.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GALE
dialogues.text: You have plenty of time. Has Keith decided on a school yet?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: We're zeroing in on a few.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GALE
dialogues.text: He's indicated to me an interest in a couple of art schools.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I don't think that's going to happen. He comes out of an art school, what's he qualified to do? I'm looking for a good business program. I think he has a good head for business.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GALE
dialogues.text: The indications I've gotten are that he's more creatively inclined.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Fine. We're looking for a business school. He can be creative in his spare time. How's he doing other- wise?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GALE
dialogues.text: Fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 18.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Grades holding up?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GALE
dialogues.text: Very well. Cliff picks up his hat and offers his hand to Mr. Gale.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Good. Thanks for the time.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GALE
dialogues.text: If you have any more questions don't hesitate to call.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff heads down an empty hallway. We MOVE AHEAD OF him TO Skinhead. He's standing at a locker, prying it open with a large screwdriver. He hears Cliff coming, turns TOWARD CAMERA, shoves the screwdriver down his front and closes his jacket. To avoid a problem, Skinhead takes the immediate offensive position. He turns as Cliff reaches him.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Can I see your hall pass? Cliff is surprised by the request.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I don't have a pass. I'ma parent. I was seeing Mr. Gale. I'm on my way out.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Please don't think me rude, sir, but we have to limit access to these hallways to students and authorized persons only. You have no idea how many unsavory types try to gain entry to the school to prey on the youngsters. They bring in contraband, controlled substances, obscene rock 'n roll lyrics. I'm telling you, sir, it's like wolves running free in the hen house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 18A.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I'm heading right out.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: I'm sure you are, sir. You have an honest face and an overall honorable body shape. I'm just alerting you to the rules. From a concerned teen to a concerned parent.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Boy, I got two kids who I wished had your attitude.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: It's refreshing, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Very. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: God bless. Cliff smiles and continues on his way. Skinhead waits a beat and returns to the locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's sitting in class. All eyes turn to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves to Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We PUSH IN ON her face as she screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's wearing paint-splattered jeans and a T-shirt. He's sitting on the back of a chair, studying a canvas he's working on. He's holding a paint brush in his teeth. It's after school. Late. He hears talking in the hallway. He looks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy and a sophomore girl, MIA, are talking in the hall- way.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He studies the situation, listens carefully.  34 35 36 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia's back is to the lockers. Hardy's standing in front of her, leaning forward, resting his elbow on the locker. Engulfing her. She's completely under his spell. He's older, he's richer, he's handsome, he's popular, he's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (softens) I want you to stay close but not too close. You back off when I say, okay? She nods, yes.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: It'll get good. Mia nods. He gives her a gentle kiss.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Both your parents work? Mia nods.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Good. Maybe I'll come over after school one day this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy and Mia. The tail end of the kiss. Hardy pulls back from her. He looks down the hall and catches Amanda looking at him. He steps back from Mia. She shoots a look to Amanda. Hardy looks at her. She heads off down the hall. Hardy smiles. He starts toward Amanda with his arms outspread.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (to himself) Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to her locker and opens it. She's angry and hurt. Hardy approaches her, acting as if he's done no- thing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You wanna go to your place? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Amanda glares at him, throws her books in her locker and grabs her coat.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Amanda tries to get away. Hardy blocks her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Yes I do. I want to know what's wrong. Amanda doesn't respond?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Mia?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm impressed, you asked her name.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: She's a friend of my little sister. Her brother was ina pretty serious car accident, and she's a little upset. Amanda glares at him. She's never been very good holding up her side of an argument with Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for you. I know you're coming, why would I be trying to make another girl? It makes no sense at all. Amanda backs down a bit. He's charming logic leaves her without an immediate counter.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: How can you be so beautiful and so insecure at the same time? In lieu of something to say, she holds her look on him.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Trust is the basis of any relationship. I trust you. He leans forward and kisses her forehead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 21. 36 37 38 39 40 4l 42

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'll drive you home. He points to a ring on his baby finger. He points to her. He slips it off, takes her hand, slips the ring on her finger and kisses her again. She doesn't say yes. She doesn't say no. Hardy takes the answer as yes.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'll get the car and meet you in front. He heads down the hall. In the direction Mia went. Amanda looks at the floor and sighs angrily. She's upset with herself. She wants to bust him but can't. She senses that she's being watched. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's standing in an open doorway looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She feels uncomfortable. Wonders if he overheard the con- versation. She'd rather keep her acquiescence to Hardy a secret.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's heard it all. He's worried for her. He knows what a stroke job she got. He gives her a two finger salute and a smile.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's too close. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He watches the empty doorway for a long beat. He picks up his brush, dips it in a jar of turpentine and cleans it o his work shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's done for the day. He lays the brush down, peels off the shirt and looks at the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: CANVAS
dialogues.text: An under-painting. Sketchy, incomplete, but very good.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 22. 43 44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clean, modern local service station. In the good part of town. The lights are on in the repair bays and the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's in the repair bay working on a Jaguar. Drummer Girl's sitting on a work bench, tapping her sticks on various surfaces.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Drummer Girl looks up.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Two flies are having sex. It's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: It happens. Keith goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: How's it feel to stand under an old Jaguar?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: About the same as standing under an old Ford. Dirty and hot.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: As she drums her way around the work bench, she hits Keit sketch book. She throws him a look back and opens the boo

dialogues.speaker: KEITH, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You wanna stand under it?

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: She leafs through the book and the sketches of Amanda. Sh finds the tattered photo.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She looks at Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He flips a tool in the box. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 22a.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She puts the photo back and closes the book

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you calling out for food?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No. Keith returns to the underside of the car.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You can call if you want. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You have any money?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: If I get hungrier, I'll call.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Don't you ever eat at home?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't like to eat alone.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Where's your mom?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Which way's the wind blowing? Drummer Girl leans back as she abruptly changes the subje

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: If you wanted to, you could blow every guy in this feeble town out of the water. From a female, popularity, sexual relationship standpoint. Keith looks at her. He doesn't understand what she means.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in blowing anybody out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: So what's the deal with Amanda Jones? Keith pauses in his work. She's hit something. He con- tinues.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (looks down) I know you're thinking about her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 24.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: We've been friends too long to bullshit each other. I know when something's going on inside you. And I know Amanda Jones is on your mind. (looks up) You've always been on your own. I like you because you don't follow everybody. You're not sheep. You don't sell your soul to belong. And it's scary to me that you might change that.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Nothing's changing.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Look me in the eye and tell me you don't think about Amanda Jones. Keith turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: So what if I do? What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. You're better than her. She's a major part of everything you don't believe in.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: She's not that much different.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Who's been lying to you? She's worse than different. She crossed town to belong to the lowest of the low. If that's the kind of person who inspires you, you've got a morality problem.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You sound a little jealous. Exactly. Drummer Girl is stunned that he nailed her feel- ings and is obliged to deny. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 25. 44 45 46

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Of what? Her? Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You're afraid that, if I went out with Amanda, we couldn't be friends.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: That would be entirely my choice and I'm not worried about it because, regardless of what I say, you're too internal to open up and ask her out, so why don't we change the subject? A BELL RINGS in the station. Keith flips his wrench into the tool box.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You brought it up.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. And I brought it up because I care about you. She doesn't. She has one thing on her mind and you don't make enough of it to matter to her. I rest my case. Keith wipes his hands on his jeans and exits the station.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Speak of the she-devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black Corvette's parked at the pumps. Hardy and Amanda. Keith walks out of the repair bay.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He slows as he recognizes Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY AND AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hardy sees Keith. Amanda looks around at him. Hardy BLOWS the HORN and holds it several long beats.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He isn't amused. A hard, cold look passes over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks around the front of the Corvette. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Twenty dollars, super unleaded. (pause, smile) Check the oil. Hardy reaches under the dash and pops the hood. Keith steps back to the pump and removes the hose. He uncaps the tank and shoves the hose nozzle in.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Be nice, or I'll make you check the tires. Keith sighs with disgust. He looks at Amanda. She avoids him.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: So, this is what you do for a living, huh? Keith looks at him. Says nothing. He walks to the front of the car. He opens the hood.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You want to cut the engine?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: My pleasure. He turns off the engine. Keith leans into the engine ca- vity and looks for the dipstick. He finds it and yanks it out. The HORN BLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. My hand slipped. Keith shakes his head at the cheap trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda isn't amused by Hardy's cruelty.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Why don't you cut it out?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Why don't you mind your own business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl slides down off the bench and walks to the door. She looks out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's checking the oil. Hardy and Amanda are talking. Keith slams the hood shut and walks back to the pump.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Keen interest in the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's watching the pump meter.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You like looking at my girlfriend, huh? Keith glares at him. Amanda gives Hardy ice.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (to Amanda) What? He likes looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Shut-up, Hardy. Keith removes the nozzle from the tank. Amanda shoots a look at him. He puts the hose back and looks at Amanda. A serious look. A look that preserves what's left of his dignity.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'd recommend you keep your eyes and your mind off my property. He starts the engine. Keith smiles. He's not frightened. Hardy holds a twenty dollar bill between his index and middle finger.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Here's ten for the gas, ten for the look. Keith looks at the bill. Pulls it out of Hardy's hand. Keith smiles. Hardy slams the car in gear and screams out of the station. Keith watches him go. He folds the twenty and puts it in his shirt pocket. He reaches behind his back and pulls Hardy's dipstick out. He tosses it in the trash barrel. He walks back to the repair bay.

dialogues.speaker: PUMP METER
dialogues.text: It reads, $8.00. Keith's only given him ten dollars worth of gas.  50 51 52 53 54 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl's seen everything. She'd like to kill Hardy. And possibly Amanda. Keith walks in.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Keith? I watched that. It was sick. If that isn't the raw, bleeding truth about Amanda Jones, I don't know what is. If you think that's interesting, you better pack it in. He picks up his tool and goes back to work under the Jagu Drummer Girl watches him. She turns up the RADIO and sits back on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls' gym. Tennis. A BELL RINGS. An INSTRUCTOR blows a whistle and waves the girls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy's car pulls up fast and stops. Amanda gets out. She's wearing a gym uniform. She reaches into the car and grabs a tennis racket. She hurries up the steps onto the courts. Hardy pulls away. Amanda's class is heading back to school. She hurries to join them, hoping to avoid de- tection. She rushes into the crowd exiting the courts and quickly adjusts to their gait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith and half a dozen other downtown boys are sitting on the bleachers. They've spent their gym period watching girls' gym. Keith sits up as he sees Amanda join her clas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM ABOVE, an Instructor cuts across the courts and call to Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Amanda Jones? Amanda slows and stops. She knows she's caught. She curses under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over the side to watch and listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Instructor catches up to Amanda. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Excusing yourself from class to leave the grounds with the boy with the hot car buys you two weeks of morning detention.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I was just talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: If all you wanted was talk, you could have gotten it without leaving school.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: What're you saying, Mrs. Albright?

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Nothing that hasn't been said before. Amanda holds her look on the Instructor.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Get inside. Amanda turns angrily and heads for the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's seen and heard the moment. A smile spreads across his face as an idea streaks through his brain.

dialogues.speaker: FIRE ALARM
dialogues.text: A hand grabs it, pulls. The ALARM GOES OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The break of dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's standing in the doorway. A puzzled, worried look on his face. He scans the room.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE DETENTION ROOM
dialogues.text: It's filled with the meanest, most wasted citizens of the school. Motor-psycho maniacs. They look to the door.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's stunned. Not a female face in the room. No Amanda Jones.  59 60 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda's talking with a male TEACHER. He's a middle-aged goof with a massive Brylcreme wave. He's clearly appreci- ative of Amanda's charms.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's really sweet of you to not make me sit in there. It's all guys. I'd feel very weird.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: I suppose it wouldn't matter if you served your detention in my office.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Actually, I have a better idea. What if I didn't serve detention at all? What if I swear I'll never do what I did again? The teacher is unable to resist. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: We'll keep this just between you and me.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (sweet and phoney) You're incredibly nice. And I love the way you wear your hair.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Really? Amanda nods. The Teacher gives her a big, goofy smile. He's fallen like a bag of Portland cement. She exits. He turns and examines his hair in the reflective surface of chrome fire extinguisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's sitting with the beasts. The Skinhead Keith con- fronted earlier is sitting next to him.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Serves you right, shithead.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: (big smile) My pleasure. They look at each other. It's a tense stand-off. A long exchange of looks that could go either way.  61 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, dreary bungalow badly in need of paint, care and repair. Sandwiched in between freeway and refinery. Keith and Drummer Girl are sitting on the porch. Semi-conscious hound is sprawled on the sidewalk below the porch. Drumme Girl's fiddling with her drumsticks.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: If you don't figure your shit out pretty soon, it's gonna get too embarrassing to be your friend. What kind of moron gives himself two weeks of detention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith looks away. He's embarrassed enough.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You familiar with the Road Runner cartoons? Beep! Beep!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I really don't need the insults.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You're going to hell in a hand- basket. Amanda Jones doesn't know you, doesn't care about you. You're trying to jerk off the impossible. How many times do I have to listen to myself tell you this? Keith holds a stare on her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You know what kind of a guy Hardy is?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Handsome, rich, popular, muscular hot, happening and capable of reducing your head to a crimson stain on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (bitter chuckle) You really know how to ferret-out the dark and ugly, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I deal in reality. Sometimes it's rank and raw. It hurts. I know. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The lifestyle I've chosen for myself opens me up to plenty of pain. If you think girls give you grief, consider what they lay on me. You can always pop a guy, but with girls you just have to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (stubborn, unmoved) Hardy's a jerk. He screws around, he treats her like shit...

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: And obviously she gets off on it. You're losing it; and when it's lost, all you are is a loser.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You have no idea how I feel, so why don't you just butt-out of it?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I know how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah? Really? You've been in love.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: There's lots of things you don't know about me.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Who've you ever been in love with? Drummer Girl turns defensive. She's exposed too many

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You want to abuse yourself, be my guest. She slides off the bench, slips the drumsticks into her belt and brushes the dust off her little ass.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Hey, Watts, nothing ventured, nothing gained, right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 33. 61

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Hey, Keith, once a fool, always a fool, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the house. Keith watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I got nothing to lose. I've already suffered every humiliation known to man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's sitting on the front porch with her baby brother in her lap, bouncing him on her knee, playing with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's across the street watching Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: As she plays with the baby, she notices something. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith is standing across the street.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She's curious why he's watching her. A little uncomfor- table. She stands up with the baby. Takes his hand and waves it to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: A bit of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith watches a moment and continues home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's in detention with the junior criminals. He's working in his sketchbook. Skinhead's next to him, scratching on the desk top with a pocket knife. The fine hand of Keith creating and the crude paws of Skin- head destroying. Skinhead looks up at Keith. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 33A. 61a 62

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Keith looks up at Skinhead. Keith nods a greeting. Skin- head stares at him. He glances down at Keith's sketchbook Keith tips it toward Skinhead so that he can see what Keith's drawing. Skinhead grabs the desk top and rips the far side from the frame. He tilts it toward Keith so that Keith can see his work. Keith nods a reluctant ap- proval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl has just come from her shower. She's wear- ing a T-shirt, drying her hair with a towel. Something catches her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda Jones. Bra and panties, combing her hair. Perfect light, perfect pose. She looks like she's in a French Lin gerie commercial.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She looks Amanda up and down. She looks at her own body. The bust inside a white T-shirt, the curve of her boyish hips, her round, little belly. She makes, to her mind, a disheartening comparison. It's a girl's body standing up to a woman's. She looks back to Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda turns profile and tilts her head back. She brings a comb to her wet hair.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: A little envy, a lot of curiosity. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Eyes closed as the hairbrush slides through golden hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full figure. T-shirt and boy's slim boxers. A SENIOR GIRL is standing across the aisle from Drummer Girl with a towel wrapped around her. (NO NUDITY.) Her clothes are strewn about the floor and bench. She looks at Drumme Girl.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are those boy's underpants? Amanda turns and looks at Drummer Girl. She smiles as she sees the boy's underpants.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. So? She picks up a drumstick off the bench. Amanda exits.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: So, I never saw a girl wear boy's underpants. Drummer Girl twirls her stick like a baton.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You ever see a girl with a drumstick shoved up her nose? Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Is that some kind of threat?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: No, that's some kind of warning. The Girl clicks her tongue and heads to the showers, leav ing Drummer Girl to herself. She tucks her T-shirt into the boxers. She turns around and looks at herself in the mirror at the end of the aisle. She strikes a feminine pose. It doesn't work for her.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: No way. MUSIC COMES UP big and CARRIES INTO AND THROUGH the NEXT SCENE.  64 65 66 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big, wide and confusing. Friday on the boulevard. An end- less procession of cars, shiny, custom extensions of thei owners' fantasy perceptions of themselves. A massive stre party. Not unlike Westwood on a Saturday night in summer Palm Springs at Easter break. MUSIC is blowing from windo and the backs of trucks. Clothes show on the sidewalks, m ing rituals, lookers and takers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's sitting on the back of a bus bench. He's serious and determined. In the midst of, but apart from, the acti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street. Hardy's crowd is dominating the curb f half a block. Hardy's at his car with Mia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl comes up behind him. She climbs up on the ba of the bench.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Come on, lost soul, we're gonna miss the show.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I don't think I'll go. Drummer Girl looks across the street. Sees Hardy and the social action. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna play dumb anymore. I know what you're hanging around for. Amanda Jones. I've been contemplating the matter and I've come to a conclusion. You interested?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Good, I'll tell you anyway. I am, biologically speaking, a babe. I have all the primary female body parts, and as far as I've been able to determine, they're functional. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (suspicious) What're you getting at? Drummer Girl clears her throat, hesitates. Searches for the proper words.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Don't take this as a come on, because it's not. It's totally operational. You are my closest personal friend, and if this jive with Amanda Jones has anything to do with sex... (nervous pause, looks away) В».. we could, maybe... you know, maybe we could... work something out, maybe. Keith is flabbergasted at Drummer Girl's intimate proposa While the suggestion is bizarre, it's also sincere and ob viously an enormous gesture. Keith is strangely touched and deeply appreciates it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's not supposed to be like that. I appreciate the offer but it's not right. This isn't about sex, Watts.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (shrugs off the decline) Yeah. Yeah. Forget it. You're right. It'd be...

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Not good.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Forget it. There's and uncomfortable pause.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I thought, as a friend, it was only proper that I offer.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Thanks. Another pause. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you really have to do this?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Keith smiles. Drummer Girl slaps him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You need some gum?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (pats his pocket) I'm covered. Drummer Girl pulls her sticks out of her belt. She salute Keith with them and exits. He watches her with a fond smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're walking down the street. Just cruising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's at his car with Mia. His back is to Amanda and Shayn as they approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda sees Hardy and Mia. She pales at the sickening re- prise of a scene she's already been through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith sees Amanda. He stands up. He steels himself. Shifts his eyes back to Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's watching Keith. She's biting her lip in dread an- ticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda approaches Hardy. He sees her. Big smile. Mia's startled and shows it. Badly. Amanda looks daggers at Hardy. It's embarrassing and humiliating. Hardy addresses Mia.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: "Bye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mia hesitates for a moment. Hardy brushes her away with a backhand sweep. She gives She tries

dialogues.speaker: MIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. (to Amanda, catty) "Bye. Hardy an adoring smile as she heads off.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hardy, I've had more than enough of this. If you were more of a person, there might be enough for two girls, but you're not.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, this jealousy crap's getting a little tedious.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You won't have to take it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What's that mean? to get around him. He blocks her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Get outta my way.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Not until we straighten this out.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: That won't work anymore, Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You walk out on me, where are you gonna go?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Amanda? Amanda turns. Hardy looks past her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's standing alone and very small across the street.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You got a minute? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She's startled to see Keith. The last person she needs right now.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: He turns to see Keith. Instant anger.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She looks at Hardy. She looks at Shayne. A notion strikes her.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: She looks at Amanda. She doesn't like the situation. Not with Hardy and certainly not with Keith. The only outcome in her mind, is a bad one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy's looking at Amanda. He doesn't trust the situation Amanda looks at Hardy. A sly smile spreads across her fac

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Amanda heads toward Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He stands his ground. Firm and strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She weaves her way through the traffic.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He watches and waits. Runs through his mind what he wants to say.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She keeps coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda reaches Keith. There's a strange, uncomfortable pause. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hi. What do you want? Amanda turns away, looks back at Shayne and Hardy and the gathering crowd. She turns back to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Are you in a hurry?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sort of. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I was going to ask you if you want to go out, but if it's too difficult...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You want to ask me out?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I think that's what I said. She stares at him. A bit of a smile. She looks back at the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A growing crowd watches the conversation. Shayne's nervou shoots glances at Hardy. His temper's simmering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda turns back to Keith. A moment; they and their con- versation. Amanda walks away. Keith backs away. Turns and disappears into the sidewalk traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes off his car as Amanda returns. He'd like to kil her. Shayne steps forward to greet Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: What'd he want?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (looking at Hardy, with a smile) He asked me out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 41. 78 719

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shayne breaks up. The others join her. Everybody but Hardy. He's serious. He knows she's grinding him.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: What'd you say? Amanda looks at Hardy. At his friends. Then back at Shayn

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I said... yes. She heads back to the sidewalk and slips into the crowd. Shayne looks at Hardy. He's supremely burned. She smiles sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: She's just mad. Shayne hurries to join Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda walks quickly through the crowd. Shayne catches up

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Go back to Hardy and straighten it out. Amanda stops. She glares at Shayne.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's okay for him to do what he wants, but it's not okay for me?

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: It's not okay. It's just the way it is. If you want to drop him, don't do it like this.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Can you drive me home?

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: He's really mad, A.J. It's scary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'll walk. She walks on, leaving Shayne behind. Shayne sighs with defeat and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't moved. He's staring across the street. His friends are patiently waiting him out. He reaches in his pocket and puts a cigarette in his mouth. He lights it, draws and exhales sharply. A FRIEND breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: What do you want to do about this? He pushes the guy aside and gets in his car. He fires up the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sunday morning. Big breakfast. Cliff's staring sus- piciously. Chewing very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: She's sneaking curious glances between bites.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She's staring. Very confused.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Same thing.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's eating and smiling. Big smile. He notices the family studying him. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: He squints. He doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Why're you smiling?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: She smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What difference does it make? I like it.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: He looks at Carol then back to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Did you do something to the car?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He looks at Cliff.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I wasn't aware that I was smiling. If it bothers you, I won't do it.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: He's not entirely convinced.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You haven't smiled in a while. I was just curious about the change.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I haven't had much to smile about, Clifford. He looks at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: She forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You have a nice smile.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Holds the smile.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Thanks, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura's held her tongue. She's been staring at Keith the whole time. Studying the change in him. Finally she speak

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: This isn't true. It can't be. It has to be like the most hilarious rumor ever floated, right? Keith doesn't respond. He just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm in town last night and I hear everybody saying that Keith asked a girl out.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: No way!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Check it out. She's scandalously popular, insanely beautiful and obviously in the middle of some emotional shoot-out to consent to date the human Tater Tot. (to Keith) What'd you do to her? Threaten her life?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I just asked her out.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Her boyfriend's a man, for Christ's sake. He's extensively easy on the eyes, he's a total buck and you're... you're Keith.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Is she nice, Keith?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Mother, the girl is sex.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: For God's sake, I'm eating!

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I'm glad you can find the time to think about girls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 45. 82 83 84

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The smile on Keith's face fades as the old subject of col lege comes up.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Between the girls and your art kick, you don't have time for anything important. I'll be dead and buried before you get off your butt and apply to a college.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ease up, Dad. Any fool can get into a college. Only a precious few can say the same thing about Amanda Jones. Cliff and Keith stare at Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Am I wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beasts are all armed with sketch pads and sticks of charcoal. Keith's working on his pad. Skinhead leans over to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: This was an outstanding idea. Most of these goons have little or no mode of creative expression. Keith gives him a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Talent's a terrible thing to waste. Skinhead holds up his pad.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Check it out. Keith looks.

dialogues.speaker: PAD
dialogues.text: A grotesque sketch of a skull with live eyeballs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith nods a reluctant approval. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: This is what my girlfriend would look like without skin. Keith nods.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: While we're on the topic of the double-breasted party machine, congratulations on your recent coup. Keith smiles. Partly out of pride, partly out of his des- criptives.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You know about Amanda Jones?

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: What? You think I live in here? I got a personal life. How'd you swing that one? She's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I don't know, Duncan, I asked her out, and she just said, "yes."

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: What do you suppose she sees in you? No offense, of course.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I guess I'll find out sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Any time somebody on the outside lifts a woman off a guat like Jenns, we can all find cause to rejoice. I'm proud of you. Punch her apron one time for me.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: You're a good man. Sorry about giving you so much grief over the years. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: If you'd just popped one time, I would have left you alone. (confidential) My bark's bigger than my bite. He gives Keith a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: You need anything, you let me know.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl's sitting with a rough, little headbanger, R He clearly likes her. He looks like Drummer Girl may be h fashion leader. They're sitting on wall.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You want me to kiss you or feel you up or anything? Drummer Girl stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You want to die young?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What kind of question is that?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Just sit next to me and shut up. Drummer Girl looks down the hall. Ray shrugs. He buys it. For a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Do I have to say anything?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: How'd you get to be so stupid?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I don't know. It just happened.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Jesus... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You don't have a boyfriend, do you?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Most of the guys I know think you're confused. I know it's all an act. You know how I know? Drummer Girl is about to scream from his annoying questio

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Because you radiate a sexual vibe. If you wanted to, you could be a girl... (snaps his fin- gers) Like that.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: This is 1987. A girl can be whatever she wants to be.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I know. My mother's a plumber.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: That explains a lot about you, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I have a great deal of respect for her. Drummer Girl sits up as something catches her eye. Keith crosses the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: She poses again. Leaning against Ray.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Look at me like you like me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Hey, that will be absolutely no trouble. Keith walks up.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Hi, Keith. What's up? She waits for a reaction from Keith.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you know Raymond?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No. He holds out his hand. Ray looks at Drummer Girl. Drummer Girl glares at him. He shakes Keith's hand.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: A pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. (to Drummer Girl) Are you busy?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Just sitting here with Raymond. Why?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I need to borrow your car. If you had something to do, I'd swing back around in a while and pick you up.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Where're you going?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I want to give Amanda a ride home. Not what she wants to hear. Ray sticks his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: By the way, congratulations; she's smokin'. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Keith shakes his hand. Drummer Girl fishes her keys out of her pocket. She flips them to Keith.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate a couple bucks for gas. Keith is surprised by the remark. He doesn't mind paying his way, it's the manner in which she asked. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: About an hour?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Fine. It's just time. Not like it means anything. Keith nods. He's confused by her attitude. He backs away. Drummer Girl slides away from Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You gotta wait around an hour? Drummer girl nods.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Do you know how much damage we could do to each other in an hour? He raises an eyebrow. Drummer Girl gets up an leaves him behind. He crosses his legs and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's sitting outside. Waiting. Amanda and Shayne exit the school. Keith stands up as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Amanda? Amanda and Shayne stop.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Can I give you a ride home? Amanda looks at Shayne. She holds her tongue. She'd love to laugh but knows better.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I was going home with Shayne. Do you know each other? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Keith shakes his head. He offers his hand. Shayne hesi- tates. Looks at Amanda before she takes it.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Hi. Keith withdraws his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I thought maybe we could talk.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Well, I was... (pause) Why don't you call me?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. Amanda feels terribly sorry for him. He's melting in the presence of the two girls. Shayne intercedes.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: (to Amanda) Why don't you go with him? Amanda looks daggers at her. Keith waits for the final an swer. He studies Shayne's involvement. Amanda looks at Keith and smiles with dread.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Where're you parked? Keith smiles with relief.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll pull around. He heads away. Amanda turns on Shayne.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot!

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: He's given you the perfect opportunity to back out. He wants to talk. Tell him it's over. Tell him, you're back with Hardy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm not back with Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: You want to tell him the truth? You want to tell him that you used him?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I didn't use him.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Oh, really? You used him to get away from Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It wasn't deliberate. It just happened. I was mad and he stepped in. It was just bad circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Regardless, the longer you wait to kill it, the worse it's gonna be. He's completely deluded. Unless of course, you're interested in him. Amanda shoves Shayne. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl's truck alone in a sea of blacktop. The starter's screaming. The engine won't turn over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A defeated sigh.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Shit, Watts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas gauge is on empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda's given up waiting for Keith. She's walking across the lot to his car. He's standing at Drummer Girl's car.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: The car won't start. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Amanda turns and yells to stop a Suzuki Samurai pulling out of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Shayne! She waves her arms. The Samurai stops, reverses and pulls around.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He watches Shayne return for Amanda. He's lost. Tried and failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda gets in front. She looks in the car then back at Keith. She waves him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith flips the keys on the seat and heads for the Samura

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in his car. Watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith climbs in the jump seat of the Samurai.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: He wants blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shayne and Amanda are in front. Keith's in the jump seat. MUSIC'S PLAYING. Shayne sneaks a look at Amanda. She re- turns it. Shayne checks Keith in her rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: D Street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A long uncomfortable pause.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's studying Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda's wearing diamond stud earrings.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He thinks it's odd that Amanda's wearing diamonds. Con- sidering where she lives. He leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Nice earrings.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She turns around to Keith. An embarrassed smile.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: They're not mine. I just borrowed them from Shayne. Another nervous smile and she turns back around.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE AND AMANDA
dialogues.text: Shayne looks at Amanda and motions to Keith. She mouths "Tell him." Amanda sneaks a look around to the back seat. She returns. Looks at Shayne. Shakes her head slightly. Shayne urges her with a stern look.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Amanda? Don't you want to say something to... (to Keith) What's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Keith. Amanda gives Shayne a sub-zero look.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He watches the back of the two girls' heads. He's cautiou and suspicious. He's feeling supremely put down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda turns in the seat and looks at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You want to forget the date. Right?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Startled that he knows.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Little change in expression. His eyes plead for truth.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: She's disgusted with Amanda. Shifts her eyes to the rear- view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She back pedals a bit.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: If you want out, I'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: If I wanted out, I wouldn't have asked you in the first place. I don't want out. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She can't say it. A limp smile and she turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Samurai is parked in front. Keith gets out.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shayne smiles obsequiously. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: My pleasure. Amanda just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He backs away from the car.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll see you tomorrow. He takes a few more backwards steps. He's afraid to turn his back on them for fear they'll tongue knife him. He back-walks until it's too stupid to continue. He turns, shoves his hands in his back pockets and saunters up to his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shayne is angry with Amanda. Amanda turns her look from Keith to the footwell.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: That was swift. I gave you the perfect window to throw him out of, and you went limp.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (defensive) Maybe you can do that sort of thing. I can't. Not in cold blood, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Then I guess you got a new boyfriend. Amanda looks at her angrily.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: He's too dim to catch a hint. If you don't tell him, he won't get it.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
