dialogues.text: So what if I go out with him once? It's not the end of the world. Amanda and Shayne look at Keith's house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Hey! What's going on? Amanda and Shayne turn quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura's leaning in Shayne's window.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Come by to see Keith?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND SHAYNE
dialogues.text: They don't know Laura from Adam. They have no idea what she's babbling about.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: We gave him a ride home.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She laughs, fake and phoney.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And he told you we live here? He is so modest. (straight) I suppose he didn't say a word about our ancestral estate in Scotland or the apartment in Paris? So modest! This isa tax thing my father picked up. Well, I have to run. I have to go over to our stables and comb out the horses. She backs away from the car.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND SHAYNE
dialogues.text: They stare at Laura like she's lost her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's at the arch to the kitchen drinking out of the orange juice carton. Laura walks in.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi, ass-face. I saw your girl- friend out in front. Keith lowers the carton suspiciously. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Did she say anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's for me to know, and you to find out. She heads up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's behind the wheel of her car. It's moving slowly. She's trying to figure out what happened to Keith. An o.c. voice calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: How far are you going?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: The nearest gas station!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl has enlisted Ray to push her car.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: How far's that?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. You're young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school is deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's sitting on the back of a chair, studying a large canvas. MUSIC'S PLAYING on his BLASTER. Dark and brood- ing.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He has a paint brush in his teeth. He's considering his work, plotting his next move. The music cuts out. He looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy's turned off the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy sits on the edge of the table. He's very calm and at ease. As if nothing's happened between them.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: How're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You nervous about something?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You look nervous. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I got no problem.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You always come to school early?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Not always. You?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: So, why today?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: About...?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (big grin) I didn't come here to talk about art. Keith doesn't reply. Hardy smiles. Eases up.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'm completely cool with the situation. The truth? I was looking for a way out of the thing with Amanda, and, weird as it is, you saved me a tough talk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I should believe that, right?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Why not? It's true. I don't want Amanda hating me. I don't want anybody hating me. So, I'd appreciate it if you'd do me a favor. Keith waits cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I don't know where you guys are going Saturday, but if you could swing it, I'd like you to come by my place. I'm having some friends over. The parents are in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You're inviting me to your house?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I've invited a lot of people. Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I don't know. You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Nothing wrong on my end. You got an inferiority complex or something? (pause) I don't know you all that well; I may not even like you if I get to know you. That's not the issue. I've known Amanda a long time; I want to stay friends. And if it's too much to bring her over, forget it. I'm sorry I asked.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Put yourself in my position. Maybe you'll understand why I don't think this sounds too good.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Put yourself in mine. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm big enough to invite a former girlfriend and the guy who stole her from me to a party. You think all this makes me look good? I've taken plenty of shit over this one.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: That's why I'm a little cautious about your motives.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'll buy that. You want the plain truth? Keith shrugs. He's not so sure he'd recognize it.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I have a lot of pride. And it's been damaged, and I don't like it. I can recover it, in my own mind at least, by showing people whose opinions matter to me that you and I are friends. Then it's not like you stole Amanda from me. Bad blood makes me look like a fool. If we're friends, it's okay. I've traded off lots of girls to friends. That's acceptable. It's not acceptable some stranger lifting Amanda off me.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: The logic's a little perverse.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Probably, but that's what it is. You tell anybody I had this conversation with you and I'll kick the shit out of you. That's a promise. He slides off the table and grabs his gym bag. He heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: It's a party. It's not the end of the world. He starts out the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's changed his mind. He wants to believe Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Hardy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy turns back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You're being straight with me?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: At this point, do you see a reason why I should play games?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll ask Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I already did. She's okay with it. Keith thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: (friendly smile) Good. It wouldn't be the weirdest thing in the world if you and I actually came out of this friends.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He smiles. A careful smile.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, it would.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Big, friendly smile. Sincere as hell.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: See ya. He swaggers out of the room.  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A volleyball clan hanging around after class. Amanda's talking with friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's watching the class. He feels that she's his now. He's comfortable and confident. A hint of a smile. He's leaning on the door jamb. He rolls back around the door to face out of the gym. His smile evaporates as he realiz he's being watched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watts is at the outside door. She's been watching him watching Amanda. She's serious and slightly wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith smiles. No change in Watts.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What's going on? Drummer Girl shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: First time in about two years you didn't have lunch with me. Is there a problem? Keith shakes his head, no. A little guilt.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Am I too weird to be around now that you're moving up? Keith doesn't particularly care for the tone.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I had something to do.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Something you never had to do in two years before? It's cool. I just wondered where you were.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I was around.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. She raises a hand and exits. Keith waits a puzzled, sad beat. He turns back to the class.  SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 64. 105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A major piece of residential architecture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, well-appointed bedroom suite. The girl has some money. Shayne's on her bed. Amanda's slouched in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: I recommend that you think twice before you make a sacrifice for this jerk.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Don't let some misfit joker tear up your life. Nobody's very excited about this affair. They see you as guilty as he is. You know what the truth is?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: From who's point of view?

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Yours. You aren't a natural fit in all this. They don't have to let you belong. You could be on the other side of the world for all anybody really cares. You like being a part of something. Don't kid your- self. It's better to be in than out. (pause) All I'm saying is, you have one more year, why make it miserable? Just go along with things. We'll have a last good year and then we're outta here forever.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm not making up with Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Then just be friends. But agree that you have to blow the date. Okay? Right now he's humiliated. Go back, get this guy out of the way and then break up. Don't get him in a corner like this. Please? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 65. 106

dialogues.speaker: 106A
dialogues.text: and

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. So what if he's humiliated. So aml. Shayne shakes her head in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: You're not in control like he is. One word from him, and you're on ice. Keith'll live. I'm sure, deep in his heart, he probably thinks you're gonna back out anyway.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: If I back out, I'm giving in to Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Fine. Give in this once. Don't make this an issue. It's not worth it. If you keep the date you lose everything.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Including you?

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: I'd never say it to your face, but I don't know what I'll feel like if I'm frozen out. You won't, either. Why risk it for nothing?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's not nothing. It's a matter of pride. If you can't understand that, I feel sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: You go through with this, and I'll be feeling sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: There's something foreboding in the remark. PUSH IN ON Amanda. MUSIC COMES IN AND CARRIES ACROSS THE CUT.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 66/67. 107 108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's sitting at a table alone. He's still riding his giant wave of delight. The place is LOUD and crowded with street people. A BAND'S PLAYING LIVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl marches into the club. She's looking for Keith. A girl on a mission. She pushes her way through the place to Keith's table. She looks at him. He looks up at her. He raises a hand in greeting. Things be- tween them are stiff and formal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 67A.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Since when do your parents let you go clubbing on school nights?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Here? She's coming here? On a school night? Did I miss some- thing? Is there a new world order?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: If you wanna knock me and make me feel bad, can you do it later?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She said she'd meet you here?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Not in those words.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: In any words? Keith shrugs off the question, for which he has no answer Drummer Girl slides into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Maybe she doesn't have ID.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Who doesn't have ID?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Maybe she doesn't like you as much as you think.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you miss me Keith? Do you miss not being around me?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: This isn't the third grade anymore. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (wistfully) I wish it was.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's not.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm not upset about her. I'm upset about you. She's the same. You're the one who's changed.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What's wrong with change?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I liked you better when you were a nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I wish you'd take a few minutes out of your day to sit down and think about what all this means to me.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: What about what it all means to me?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It means, you don't have a love- sick, depressed, boring friend anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She doesn't love you. It's a joke. It's all a joke. Keith scoffs at the remark.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'd bet my hands on it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You don't want to make that bet.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) I gotta split. This is too much agony for me. I've been thinking about you and me a lot lately and I came to a conclusion that I didn't want to deal with, but now that we talked, I can't hide it anymore. (deep breath) I think we'll get along much better if we don't spend so much time together anymore.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Because. I'm driving you crazy, you're driving me crazy, and I'd rather have you think good things about me and not see me than see me and hate me. I can't afford to have you hate me, Keith. The only things I care about in this life are me, my drums and you. Adios. She walks away from the table. Keith calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Watts! She stops and turns. Looks at him a moment, turns and disappears into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: A part of himself is walking out. There's no obvious so- lution to the problem. He's torn between love and friend- ship, and love has to win. He turns back. He looks at his watch. He fears that Amanda won't show. He slides down in the chair to wait it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big, new, anonymous mall. Laura is sitting on a planter talking to a group of her friends.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm his sister. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you're a brother or a sister, you're in. It's like they have to accept you, or the whole social structure caves in.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: You get to go to parties?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course. I'm probably going to the one Saturday at Hardy Jenns'. Keith's going with Amanda. We might double.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: Who'd go out with you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The choices are limitless.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Can we go, too?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Eventually. If you stay cool.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: You're lying.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: Yeah. Friend 2 looks down the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy and a group of his friends are hanging around out- side a record store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend 2 turns back to Laura.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: (big grin) If you're so tight with Hardy's people, why aren't you down there with them? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Because I'm here with you, twerp.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: Maybe you're here because you're false.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Is this a challenge or something?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: Yeah. Laura slides down off the planter.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I was hanging with you fungi in a vain effort to cool you out, but all I get is breeze, so, cie la vie. She heads down the mall. The girls watch curiously. Laura sneaks glances back at them. She's over-estimated the si- tuation badly.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: They watch Laura head down the mall.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: She's a liar. Her brother loathes her. He'd never let her play with his rep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura strolls down the mall. She slows as she reaches the boys. She looks back at the girls, strikes an attitude an flips them off. She slides up on another planter, adjacen to the group. It looks like she's a part of the group.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She's not really connected to the people. She's just on the edges. She puts herself in a sexy, careless attitude. The boys are below and to the side of her. Unaware of her

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Amanda has to bring him. What else can she do? She can't take the pressure. She'll bring him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 72. 111 112

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: A puzzled look as she eavesdrops.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: Hardy continues his conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: The party'll go down as expected; Amanda'll blow in with her guy; We'll nail him and go back to business as usual. It's real simple.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She's devastated by what she's overheard. Stunned. All the evil she's done on Keith comes rushing back on her. Tears gather in her eyes. She leaps down off the planter and takes off down the mall.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRLS
dialogues.text: They watch as Laura charges past, breaking in and out of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND 2
dialogues.text: Hey, Laura! Did they send you for beer? The girls laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura bursts out the doors and runs to the bike rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's night. Lights are burning. Laura rides up on her bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's laying in bed looking at the sketch of Amanda hangin on the wall at the foot of his bed. MUSIC'S PLAYING. Some thing lonesome and pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura's listening at the door. She slips a table knife in the lock and compromises it. She turns the knob and opens the door.  73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands at the door watching. Troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith turns slowly to the door and sees Laura. He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I guess you wouldn't be you if you knocked before breaking into my room.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She's serious and grieved.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Keith. I thought if I knocked, you wouldn't open up, and I want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith sits up on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: This should be interesting. Laura walks in and sits on the edge of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I heard something tonight at the mall. Hardy Jenns and his guys were there, and I heard them talking about you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I've jumped on you pretty hard for a pretty long time, Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What's your point?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You know the blood's thicker than water stuff? Keith rotates his finger, signalling her to get to the gi of her intrusion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 74.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It's true. I thought I hated you. I really did. But I don't.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Keith, it's a joke. Amanda Jones. The date. The party. The whole thing's a joke. She's going out with you to get you to Hardy Jenns' house so he can mess you up. Keith freezes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I heard Hardy say it. I heard him. It's true.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: A joke?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Keith. For everything. She backs slowly out the room and closes the door. We HEA the CLICK of the LOCK. Laura's used her butter knife to secure the door for Keith. MUSIC COMES UP. Keith turns to the window.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Stares out the window. He realizes what a fool he's been. How he's turned from his friends. How exposed he's let himself get. He looks at a sketch of Amanda on his wall.

dialogues.speaker: SKETCH
dialogues.text: Amanda looking over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He shifts his look from the sketch to out the window. He stares into the night.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Keith walks up to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's beating on her drums. MUSIC'S BLASTING. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's soaked with sweat. She's wearing shorts and a torn piece of T-shirt for a bra. The room is drab and dingy. The total value of the contents including the drums and stereo is nine cents. It's a mess. The walls are decorate with graffiti. The door opens, and Keith walks in. Drum-в mer Girl looks up at him. She smiles and continues drum- ming. Keith walks over and sits on the bed. Drummer Girl reaches over with a drumstick, tips the tone arm on the turntable and sends it into reject. The music ends.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You're getting really good.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (formal, stiff) I'm working on it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You're brothers don't mind you playing this late?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't know. I never asked. To what do I owe the honor?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I got a little problem. Drummer Girl senses big trouble. She gets off her seat an lays her sticks down.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You know how you told me that the thing with Amanda's a joke?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's a joke.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You mean a joke, as in a joke on you? Keith nods. Drummer Girl winces. As angry as she was at him, she understands how bad he feels.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Laura overheard Hardy talking about it. Amanda's supposed to get me over to Hardy's house, and they're gonna pound me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Keith leans back on her bed. He reaches behind his head and comes up with a bra. Drummer Girl snatches it away with her drumstick.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Good thing you found out about it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: She doesn't like Hardy. I know it. The guy uses her up and down.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You're playing word games. The fact is, she sucker-punched you and set you up to lose your face.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You're gonna go through with this?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I have to.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You think it's just Hardy?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: If the guy wants me, he'll get me. I don't have to go toa party. He'll find another chance. I'm not gonna hide.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Leave it alone.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I can't?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Because I want to stand up to them.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, forget it. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's impossible. They rule the world, and that's a fact, and you fight it, you get crushed. Another year and you're gone. It's better to swallow pride than blood.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You don't think that. I'm not going to believe that you think that. Drummer Girl is completely frustrated. She walks to the window and looks out the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm not giving in to them any- more. Not for another year. Not for another minute. Drummer Girl turns from the window. She can't argue him.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll do whatever I have to do to make her see me for what I am. Drummer Girl smiles. She climbs onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: All right. I get it. Keith leans back on the bed. Drummer Girl lays down next to him. He turns his face to hers.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I was so tough with you.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Me, too. He touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You always hurt the ones you love.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: So, when're you beating the shit out of Amanda Jones? Keith looks away and laughs. Drummer Girl doesn't laugh. She just lays still, feeling his body against hers.  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Shayne and a couple of anonymous friends are in the quad, talking. Keith crosses to them. Amanda turns. Shayne sneaks a look at her. Keith walks up.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What time do you want me to pick you up Saturday? Amanda hesitates. She looks at her friends. She's embar- rassed.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You have to check with them to see what time you can go out?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No. I was just... She doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You just what? It's a simple question.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I have to think, okay?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Don't strain yourself. I'll pick you up at 7:30. If that's a problem, call me. He turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Shit. What was that?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: What an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Shut up. Amanda exits in the opposite direction of Keith.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Is she serious about him?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Sounds like it to me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: You have a guy like that dogging you around for a week and see how clearly you think, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda is crossing the quad. Keith calls to her. She stop He catches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What time do you want me to pick you up Saturday? Amanda hesitates. She looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shayne and a couple of FRIENDS are across the quad. They glance across at Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH AND AMANDA
dialogues.text: She looks back at Keith. She concerned.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You have to check with your friends to see what time you can go out?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No. I was just... She doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You just what? It's a simple question.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE AND FRIENDS
dialogues.text: They watch Amanda and Keith. They're not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Keith talking.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE AND FRIENDS
dialogues.text: They exchange looks and turn away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND KEITH
dialogues.text: Amanda closes the conversation. She's anxious to get away from him.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Pick me up whenever you want.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: 7:30? If you have a problem, call me. She nods. He turns and exits. Amanda walks over to Shayne and her friends. They're carrying on a conversatio They don't acknowledge Amanda when she walks up. They continue talking as if she wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: I hate going to Mexico. I'd much rather go to the Virgin Islands.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I think we're going to Aspen over Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I said, hi.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Aspen's okay. There's not all that much to do at night, though.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Come on you guys. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Mostly private parties. I had a pretty good time last spring.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Shayne?

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: It's a totally different place in the spring. A lot more college people. Amanda figures it out. She's been put on ice.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: True. But what's in the Virgin Islands? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Try a million guys.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: This is it, right? I'm over?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I'd go anywhere if I could bag the family and be on my own.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Thanks. She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: I almost had my parents talked into letting me go to Ricky's place in Santa Fe over Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Were his parents there?

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: No. There's a pause in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: She's gone. Shayne looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda disappears into the school.

dialogues.speaker: CU. SHAYNE
dialogues.text: She loathes what she's done. But considers that she had n choice. She looks at Holly.

dialogues.speaker: CU. HOLLY
dialogues.text: She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: It's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: CU. SHAYNE
dialogues.text: She doesn't really believe it. She walks away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You say you tried to convince her.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But she's my friend. What are friends for.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Now, Shayne, you and I are grown- up enough to know what friends are for.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Yeah. And I did my level best.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Sure you did. Now come on and let's get into some better company before I have to go wash my hands.

dialogues.speaker: SHAYNE
dialogues.text: You really are something, Holly.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: (beaming smile) Aren't we all. Shayne nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda's crossing a playing field, heading to the locker room. She slows as she sees Hardy waiting at the locker room door. The pause is momentary. She gathers her strength and continues.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Get lost, Hardy. He blocks her entrance to the door with his arm.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You're still mad? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Can we talk?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No. She shoves his arm away and walks into the girls' locker room. Hardy goes right in with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda stops and turns to Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: This is cute.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's too late.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I've been in agony over this.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: What do I have to do to convince you that I love you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Start by leaving me alone. I'm late. She turns; he grabs her and turns her back.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: You're going out with low-life just to hurt me, and you know what? It's working. It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You've got everybody applying pressure to get me to your house so you can prove what a stud you are by beating him up.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Where'd you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Give me some credit, will you?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: True, I invited him. Not to beat him up. But just to show I'm a good loser.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You're not a good loser. You're just a loser, period. She pulls her arm free. A WHISTLE BLOWS. Amanda looks around. Hardy looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Instructor who busted Amanda earlier is standing be- fore them. She's angry and mean.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY AND AMANDA
dialogues.text: She's scared. He could care less.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I'm talking to Amanda. Can you give me two minutes to finish it up? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: She's outraged.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: He owns the world.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Do you mind? There's nothing in here that I haven't seen before.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: She advances on Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: HARDY AND AMANDA
dialogues.text: He holds up his hand to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: It's Hardy Jenns. With two 'n's. (to Amanda) Can I drive you home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Instructor grabs Hardy by the collar. He from her and back to the door.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: I really appreciate this, lady. Be a bitch, why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Consider yourself reported. 81. yanks away He ignores the Instructor and backs out the door.

dialogues.speaker: HARDY
dialogues.text: Amanda? Your reputation's hanging in the balance here. Play me around, and you'll have a real lonely year.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: So I hear. She walks into the locker room. Hardy watches her go. He backs away, turns and angrily kicks the door open.  SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 81a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A destroyed Volkswagen Thing pulls into the station and stops. Skinhead gets out. He walks into the repair bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's at the workbench working on a carburetor. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skinhead's in the open bay.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He doesn't know why Skinhead's come to see him. He shrugs

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skinhead walks over to the bench. Keith wipes his hands on a rag.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Good money?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Looking at it as a career?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: But you can always fall back on it. Good move. Listen, I heard about the bullshit with Amanda Jones and how you're getting set up. Keith sighs. Does the world know?

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: There aren't a lot of things I believe in, but one of them is, nobody sets up nobody. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 81B.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hardy Jenns is pretty rough, but he can be taken. He only works in a pack. We get him alone and bing!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I don't want to beat anybody up.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: You pop a knuckle and the art gig's historical, right? Perfectly understandable.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I don't want a fight. That won't solve anything.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Look, one of the main reasons I'm such an asshole is, guys like Hardy Jenns. I can't deal with getting looked down on by them. I'd rather have somebody inject me with hot lead than get laughed at. I can't handle it. My father says I'm ruining my life to prove that I'm worth something. He's very perceptive for someone his age. Keith smiles at the extreme remarks.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: I figure, spending two weeks next to you in morning jail qualifies us as friends, and I told you I'd help you. I want to help you. If you don't want to nail Jenns, tell me what I can do for you. Keith is at a loss as to what Skinhead could possibly do for him.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: If you're thinking about pounding Amanda Jones, I don't go in for that.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: The offer is help enough, okay? I appreciate it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/13/86 81c.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: If you can't think of some way that I can help you, I'll feel outrageously worthless and crippled. Promise me, you'll think about it. Keith offers his hand. Skinhead looks at it. It's dirty. He hesitates, but shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Cool. In the meantime, can I cop a gallon of gas? I'll pay you back Monday.  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith and Drummer Girl are walking down the railroad trac

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you think anybody can tell you're carrying $4,200?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Where would I get $4,200?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: True. You want me to tell you one more time that I think you're crazy?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You've been hoarding that cash for years, right?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (pause) How bad is your dad gonna ream you?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (with a smile) You won't be able to measure it with existing technology.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: He's a miser, huh?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No. It's just real important to him that I go to college.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: He didn't go, huh? Keith shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I rag you a lot about your parents and family, but it's only because I'm jealous. It's gotta feel pretty good to have somebody watching out for you like he does. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: He's still gonna kill you, though, right?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (long pause) Is it her body, or her face?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Amanda? I don't know. It's everything. Drummer Girl considers the remark.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: My grandmother once told me I'd have big boobs when I grew up. Keith sneaks a look at her boobs.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What happened? Drummer Girl shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't know. I guess I'm just lucky.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (pause) I want to know why you're helping me with all this?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Should I not help you? You're my friend. Friends help each other.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What do I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: No way on earth to put it into words. She walks ahead of Keith and heads down the embankment. Keith considers what she's said. No conclusions. A dis- tant TRAIN WHISTLE BLOWS.  124 125 126

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith cuts across the lawn to the back door. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith comes in the back door. Silently. He carefully closes the screen door. The faintest CLICK of the screen door HANDLE brings on a call from Cliff in the living roo

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Keith? Keith issues a silent curse for being caught. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff's on the couch with the college brochures, a calcu- lator and sheets of paper. He's working figures. He turns to the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Hey! I got some great news today. Keith looks across at Cliff.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Those treasury bills I said were at the B of A at 6 and 3/4% (big smile) They're at 7%. Keith holds his wince as Cliff hits a tender subject.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: That means, you're earning an extra sixteen dollars a year per bill. Keith manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You've got your first years money Keith. Now all you have to do is get off your can and pick a school to spend it on.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll get into it. He heads upstairs. Cliff turns back to his figures. 84.  127 128 129 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks in and takes off his jacket. He tosses it on the chair and sits down on the bed. He takes a huge wad of money out of his pocket. He unfolds it and looks at it. Leafs through it, thinking. He glances up at the sketch of Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Looking at the picture. MUSIC COMES UP and CARRIES THROUG the next sequence.

dialogues.speaker: SKETCH
dialogues.text: FULL FRAME. Amanda's head is caught in a turn. Big smile. The sketch becomes LIVE ACTION. Amanda turns and heads down a mall with her best friend, Shayne, the tall, elega black girl. They're laughing and talking. As they CLEAR FRAME, we see Drummer Girl slide out from behind a pillar She follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shayne and Amanda are browsing the store. Drummer Girl slips in the door. She crosses to the shoes and keeps tab on Amanda as she pretends to look at the shoes. They're obviously revolting silly things to her.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: A young woman is bent over, looking closely at a pair of shoes she's trying on. She stops. Looks to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl's patent-leather work shoes with the studs.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: She looks up at Drummer Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl is looking down on her. Tough and mean.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: She goes back to her shoes, intimidated by Drummer Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda looks through the racks of clothes. As she abandon a rack, Drummer Girl takes her place, looking at what she bought. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND SHAYNE
dialogues.text: They're sifting through hanging blouses. Shayne tugs Amanda's sleeve to get her attention. She motions her head for Amanda to look behind her. Amanda discreetly turns and looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl is doing a bad job of pretending to be pre- occupied.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Shayne whispers to Amanda. They leave the blouses and go into the dressing rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl slides over to the blouses.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND SHAYNE
dialogues.text: They're watching from the dressing area. Shayne smiles. She has an idea. She exits the dressing room. Amanda follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl watches out of the corner of her eye as Aman and Shayne walk past her back. They clear, and once again Drummer Girl follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Shayne walk down the mall. Drummer Girl is be- hind them. They turn into a store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Shayne walk in. Amanda doesn't get what Shayne doing. But she follows. A beat, and Drummer Girl slips into the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross to a rack of suits, and Shayne starts looking through them. She motions to Amanda to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's looking at a rack of belts. Keeping a watchful eye on the ladies.  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Shayne leave the suits. Shayne leads. They move to the back of the store. Drummer Girl leaves the belts and looks at the suits.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She's looking through the suits. She's puzzled. She looks at the sleeve, holds it, thinks for a minute. Realizes that something's very wrong. She looks up and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Shayne are looking directly at her.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She realizes that she's been caught. A beat and the embar rassment hits. She turns back to the suits and curses her self for letting herself get trapped.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND SHAYNE
dialogues.text: Shayne looks at Amanda with a smile. Amanda isn't amused the prank. She exits. Shayne doesn't know what she means. A beat and she follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda stops at the door. Shayne continues out into the mall. Amanda looks back at the suit rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl is staring at the sleeve. She looks back at Amanda. A hurt, angry look.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: A look of mild compassion. But still curious. What does the girl want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl sitting on a work bench. Keith's working on the vintage Jaguar.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I think we've pretty much covered everything. All the arrangements have been made.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You know what you're going to say?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Whatever comes to mind.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You want to plan it out a little?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It'll sound false. I'll just do what my instincts tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Okay. Keith gives her a smile. He slams the hood shut and wipes his fingerprints off the paint.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Not an altogether terrible mode of transportation, huh? She has something on her mind that's hard to bring forth.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: One last detail hangs. Keith tosses the rag and leans back on the car.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Don't think I'm being weird, but what if she wants you to kiss her? Keith gives her a deadpan look.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Well, then I guess I'll just have to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I didn't put in all this time and effort to have you blow it all because you're too vain to admit you're not the king of male sexuality. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 89.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Amanda Jones is no minor leaguer who'll be swept off her feet at the touch of your amateur lips. This babe has plenty of battle scars.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I think I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm not knocking you. In this age of high-tech diseases, you're probably smart keeping to yourself. I just think that maybe you should consider whether or not you feel you can deliver a kiss that kills. A wave of doubt washes over Keith. He pulls a swift rever She waves

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You think I can't?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: If you say you can, you probably can.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm not an expert.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: It's fine. I was just going to work on it with you, but if you're comfortable...

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: How do you work on it? him over to the bench.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Pretend I'm a girl, okay? (corrects herself) I mean, pretend I'm her. Amanda. It's a big stretch, but try it. Keith shrugs. He can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: What do you do with your hands?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It depends. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: It doesn't depend, they go on her hips.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Do it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Put your hands on my hips. Keith stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: This is just as weird for me as it is for you. Let's be men about it. Keith takes a step to the bench. Another step and he's face to face with her. He gingerly lays his hands on her hips. She grabs his wrists and plants the hands firmly on her tight, little hips.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Look in my eyes. Keith looks into her eyes. He laughs. Drummer Girl glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't have to do this, you know.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's just...

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Grow up a little. Keith resets, clears his smile and looks into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She'll probably do this... She puts her arms around his neck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I watch a lot of TV. (pause) Close your eyes. He closes his eyes. She takes the opportunity to steel herself. She moves slowly toward him. Her lips part. She hesitates for a brief moment. He opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes closed!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Why are you staring at me?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm seeing if you look stupid.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: You're fine. Keith slams his eyes shut. She repeats the move and then gently puts her lips to his.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH'S HAND
dialogues.text: His fingers squeeze Drummer Girl's hip.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL'S HAND
dialogues.text: She clutches his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl's legs close around Keith's waist.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH AND DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She suddenly catches herself, opens her eyes and breaks the kiss. She pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Okay, fine!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Lesson's over. You're cool.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (smiles) You're blushing.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. The day I blush...

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: That was very nice. You're pretty. Drummer Girl raises a leg, plants it on Keith's belly and fires him across the garage. She jumps down off the bench

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: If this is how you repay a favor I don't know if I'm rich enough to be your friend. She storms out of the garage. Keith is dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I didn't mean anything! I'm sorry. I was kidding.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She stops. Maybe she'd rather he wasn't kidding. She turn

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's genuinely sorry he's offended her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Don't be mad, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I won't tell anybody about this.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She nods. She turns and heads down the road. She wipes her mouth on her sleeve. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He watches her go. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'll see you tonight! He leans against the Jaguar and watches her disappear dow the road. "Miss Amanda Jones" by the Rolling Stones COMES UP and CARRIES ACROSS AND THROUGH TO THE NEXT SEQUENCE.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA JONES
dialogues.text: She's looking in the mirror with wet hair, fresh from her shower. She's staring at herself, unsure about what she's embarking on.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She's staring in her broken mirror. A towel around her shoulders. Like a jock. Wet hair. Right from the bath.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA JONES
dialogues.text: She's blow-drying her hair.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She's towel drying her hair. Short, hard bursts.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She opens a make-up case, loads a brush and does her face

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Opens a make-up case. Loads a brush, turns her face to th mirror and blots out a small lightning bolt tattoo on her neck.

dialogues.speaker: LEG
dialogues.text: A stocking is drawn up the leg. Who's leg?

dialogues.speaker: BRA
dialogues.text: A front clasp is fastened.

dialogues.speaker: WAIST
dialogues.text: Panty top rises INTO FRAME and snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closet. A hand yanks a blouse off the rack.

dialogues.speaker: GARMENT BAG
dialogues.text: Plastic clothing store bag. It's torn open.

dialogues.speaker: BLOUSE
dialogues.text: A button's fastened.

dialogues.speaker: PANTS FLY
dialogues.text: Up with the zipper

dialogues.speaker: WRIST
dialogues.text: Bracelets are loaded on a wrist.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERS
dialogues.text: In quick order a ring is slid onto four fingers.

dialogues.speaker: FOOT
dialogues.text: Slides into a boot.

dialogues.speaker: LIPS
dialogues.text: Lipstick, red and wet.

dialogues.speaker: EAR
dialogues.text: Black glass studs.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER EAR
dialogues.text: An earring is removed.

dialogues.speaker: PURSE
dialogues.text: Hand loads gum and money.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD
dialogues.text: Turns from the mirror so we only see a flurry of hair.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND HEAD
dialogues.text: Same thing.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He's in the shower. The water's beating on his face. sings to the TRACK. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (sings)

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: He's in the bathroom. He's listening with a rising anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith is outlined in the plastic shower curtain.

dialogues.speaker: TOILET HANDLE
dialogues.text: Cliff's index finger pushes the handle, flushing the toil

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He continues singing.

dialogues.speaker: ROUND AND ROUND AND ROUND...
dialogues.text: The water suddenly runs cold. Keith's eyes open in shock. He screams. It lays nicely against the song as it comes t a sudden end.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! He rips the shower curtain aside to reveal Cliff staring him.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Dad! What're you doing? Cliff continues to stare.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Get dressed. I want to talk to you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He knows it's the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cliff's standing at the window. Keith walks in. He's wear ing jeans and an unbuttoned shirt. Cliff turns as Keith comes in. There's and exchange of looks.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I want to know what's wrong. Keith doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Are you in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Were you at the bank recently? Keith blanches. His father knows. The game is up.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You withdrew the college money? Keith realizes there's no point in lying.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: It's going back, pal. Every last damn cent is going back. You don't get this close to something and piss it away.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's not going back, because I don't have it. I spent it.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: What'd you buy? A car? Whatever you bought, you can take it back. And you're gonna take it back.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Dad, I can't. I don't want to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 97.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I don't care what you want. The money's going back in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You're not listening. I don't have it. I can't get it back.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You had no right touching that money.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I had every right. I earned it.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Where's the money?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Dad, listen to me. The money's not important.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You don't know what the hell you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I know what I'm saying. You just never listen. You only hear what you want. Listen to me. I'm not going to college. The money's gone. It's not coming back. It's over. The whole dream. It's not what I want, it's what you want. I never wanted it. I just didn't have the guts to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You're eighteen years old, for Christ's sake!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Next year I'm nineteen. Then I'm twenty. When does my life belong to me? Cliff doesn't have an answer. It's something he's never considered.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm going out with a girl tonight. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 98.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cliff Cliff son's Keith

dialogues.speaker: KEITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's beautiful, and everybody's in love with her, and she's going out with me. In the eyes of most people around here, I'm nothing. And probably in her eyes, too. She's going out with me to get back at her boyfriend. They've got this plan together to beat me up...

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: People at school. It's all right. I can handle it. The point is, nobody thinks anything of me. To them, I'm a zero, and so I don't start agreeing with them, I'm going through with this date. I'm going to show this girl that I'm as good as anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You're gonna impress her with money? That's not a solution, Keith.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Didn't you have guys at school who didn't fit in? thinks about it. Recalls a few.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Well, I'm one of those guys. looks down. He's never given much thought to his social status. He assumed that everything was fine.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I thought things were going all right for you. shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I like art, I work in a gas station, my best friend's a tomboy. These are not things that fly too well in the American high school. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 99. 165

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: So, what's the money for?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: The date.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: You were serious? Keith nods his head. Dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: How can you blow all that money?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It doesn't make much sense unless you're me. But I did it. If you want to nail me, I'll understand. Tonight's for my future. No matter what happens, I'll come out of it knowing that I mean something, if only to myself, and that's worth forty-two hundred dollars. If I have to wait a year before I go to college, if I go to college, then that's the way it has to be. Cliff looks at him long and hard. He nods. A bit of a smile. Pride. He slaps his knee and stands.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Get dressed. You're gonna be late. Keith offers his hand. Cliff takes it. He shakes Keith's hand and pulls him into an embrace.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Thanks. They break embrace.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: If it's legal, I don't care what you did with the money.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's all square. Cliff reaches in his pocket and comes up with a couple of bills. He sets them on Keith's desk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 100.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: So long as you're blowing it here's a little more.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm covered, Dad. It's not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Keep it, or I'll feel lousy.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: For not taking ten minutes out of the last ten years to realize how lucky I am to be able to call you my son. Keith smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Don't be a hero. Keith shakes his head. Cliff grabs the door knob and opens the door. Laura's standing in the doorway. She's holding a butter knife.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi. I was just coming to tell Keith that Watts is downstairs to pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Don't bug him. He's in a hurry. Cliff steps around her and exits. Laura hangs back.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Keith? Do you think it's possible that Dad'll stay this cool, or do you think he'll go back to normal in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I think he'll stay cool.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (smiles) I'll pray. Good luck tonight. I got all my friends crossing their fingers for you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 101/102. 165

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Keith puts his arms around her. She puts hers around him. He kisses her forehead. She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You want me to lock up for you? She twists the butter knife.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dusk. Magic hour. A HERALDIC MUSIC STRING and the Jaguar we've seen Keith working on glides INTO FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR HANDLE
dialogues.text: The driver's door opens, and Drummer Girl gets out. She's completely transformed. She's forsaken the macho image an is coiffed and dressed in a fashion that isn't a sell-out but that is more true to her biological status. What re- mains of her old wardrobe are the red gloves. She walks around the car to the rear door and opens it. Keith steps out. It's a new Keith. No grease, no blackness. Bright, new, strong. He offers his hand to Drummer Girl. She takes it and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Gimme a break. Look at us, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I think you look tremendous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: It's too bad my grandmother bit the dust. She'd be proud. I'm wearing a bra. Keith smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes, it's true. I broke down and got me a boulder holder. It's very weird and highly uncomfortable, and I guess this is personal, and I don't know why I'm talking like this; it's none of your business, so go get your skag and let's roll. She leans back against the car. Keith salutes her and hea up to the house. Drummer Girl fidgets with the bra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS. Amanda comes down the stairs. She looks better than ever. She yells a farewell on the way down.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: That's for me! "Bye!

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: What time'll you be home?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Early!

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Tell Hardy hello for us!

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I will. She pulls open the door. Freezes. She takes a closer look Amanda is startled by the change in Keith.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hi. Keith nods to her.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You ready? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You look. (diplomatic) Different.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Than what?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Before.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No grease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl's standing at the car with the back door ope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Keith come down off the porch. She slows as sh see the Jaguar. She looks at him again.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Is that your car?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: For right now it is.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: How'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Is that important? Do you not want to ride in it?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's fine. I just wondered.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I can tell you. It's not very exciting. (pause) It's stolen. A little hint of a smile spreads across her cheeks. (CONTINUED)
SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 105.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I didn't hot-wire it. I'm working on it at the gas station. I didn't think you'd be impressed with the rotting mini, so I borrowed this.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Does the owner know about it?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No. Should I call him? She smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: No? Yeah, lets call him. He starts back to her house. Amanda stops him.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I was just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl smiles sheepishly as Keith and Amanda step to the car. There's a moment of recognition as Amanda and Drummer Girl exchange looks. Amanda recognizes the clothes Drummer Girl's wearing as the clothes she was looking at when Drummer Girl was tailing her at the mall. Drummer Girl knows she knows.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's me. Amanda gets in the car. Keith gives Drummer Girl a wink and gets in. She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm gonna love this one. I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jaguar is parked in front of a barbeque place. The neighborhood's dicey. Drummer Girl's behind the wheel, listening to the RADIO, tapping her fingers on the roof. A couple of kids are looking at the car.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Touch it and you die.  SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 106. 171

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real item. Jammed with patrons. LOUD and rowdy and smoky and tough.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Be honest. How many guys have you gone out with who would have the class to bring you to a place like this?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I thought so.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Look, how this happened is as much a mystery to me as it is to you. And I'm not any more thrilled than you. Okay? So stop giving me attitude.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I'm giving you attitude?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Like in the gym Friday. Pulling the power play with the he-man bullshit about I have to ask my friends permission. I didn't care for it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's true, though, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: At least I have friends.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Do you? Really?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hey, you want to end this right now?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You don't want to eat? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 107. 172 173

dialogues.speaker: KEITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's ordered, you may as well bag some free chow. Sit back and enjoy the atmosphere. Pretend I'm dead.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I wish. Amanda turns around and looks into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty people up to their elbows in barbeque. One of them waves a rib at her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She smiles sheepishly at him and returns the wave. She turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's smiling. Amanda doesn't know why. A waitress serves a huge platter of ribs. Keith keeps smiling. Amanda stares at the ribs. Then looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What'd you expect? I work ata gas station. My inheritance'll be a Timex watch and a lawn mower.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I can't believe you'd bring me to a place like this to eat something like that.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's delicate. It's elegant. He's smiling full-out. She breaks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Are you aware that you just smiled? What could that mean? Her smile grows. She can't stop it. It's all so ridicu- lous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummer Girl's out of the car. Standing at the window, looking in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 107A. 174

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Keith are talking. It's obvious that the situ- ation has improved.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: She turns from the window. A look, serious concern, on he face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda tries to daintily eat a dripping rib.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You work a lot?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Not really. Twenty hours a week maybe.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Sometimes. What about you? Do you work?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You ever worked?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No. But I'll work the summer.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You didn't work last summer? Amanda shakes her head, no.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Beach? Amanda smiles. She knows it's a gentle insult.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Where do you get your money?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Why don't we talk about something else? This is a drag. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86 107B. 175

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What do you want to talk about? Sports? Amanda smiles. Keith lets her off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Do you wrestle? She bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith and Amanda come out. Drummer Girl's at the wheel. She glances over. Keith's waiting for her to open the door. She groans and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I can get the door. Amanda reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: I got it. Sorry I wasn't more on the ball, I was comatose. She walks around to the door and opens it. Amanda gets in. Keith hands Drummer Girl a paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I brought you something.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: (facetiously) For me? A gift?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I thought you might be hungry.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Jeez. Thanks. Eating ribs and driving, that's about as handy as skiing and doing your taxes.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: I thought you could eat at the next stop.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Thanks, Keith. Can I book time to take a leak? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL - Rev. 8/8/86

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Keith leans over the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (to Amanda) One second. He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You volunteered to do this, you know. I was all prepared to drive myself, and you said, 'Oh, no, I'll drive, so you can talk.' Remember?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: It was this morning, moron, of course I remember.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: So, why are you giving me shit? She grabs the bag from Keith and walks around the front o the car. Keith doesn't understand why she's being so dif- ficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda's watched the little spat. Drummer Girl gets in and starts the engine. Keith gets in. He gives Amanda a smile and Drummer Girl, a puzzled look.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: If my dinner reeks, let me know, I'll put it in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER GIRL
dialogues.text: Then, we're off. She drops the car in gear and pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's behind the wheel. Amanda and Keith are in the back seat. Keith's looking at Drummer Girl. He's annoyed with her. She glances in the mirror and catches his look to he She turns her eyes forward, feeling as if she let out too much emotion. She flips on the RADIO to help disguise her exposure. Amanda slumps down in the seat and lays her hea back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She rolls her head to the side and looks at Keith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith's looking at Drummer Girl.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She looks forward. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. The museum is long closed. The Jaguar is parke in front. Drummer Girl opens the door for Amanda and Keit They get out. Amanda looks up at the building.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: What're we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: It's an art museum.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I know. But what're we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You don't like art?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but isn't it closed?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean we can't go in. Keith leads Amanda up to the building. She doesn't get it Drummer Girl leans back against the car. All her hopes ar slipping away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Keith approach the dock. Keith gives her a han up. She clumsily climbs the dark steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy door opens to reveal Skinhead from the detention room.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Welcome. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA AND KEITH
dialogues.text: Amanda looks curiously at Keith. He gives her a smile. It's okay. He leads her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Keith walk in. A SECURITY GUARD is standing be hind Skinhead. He's a portly, middle-aged man.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: No monkey business.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Dad? Freeze it, okay? Please? The guard reaches for his keys. He crosses to an interior door and unlocks it. He opens it and holds it open for Ke and Amanda. Keith holds his hand high. Skinhead slaps it.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Anything for a friend, pal. He raises an eyebrow in Amanda's direction, indicating hi opinion of her. Keith smiles and nods. Yes, the woman is molten. Keith puts his hand on the small of Amanda's back and leads her into the museum. The guard closes the door. He turns back to Skinhead.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: I get fired for this, and you're in the dumper, Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Absolutely. The guard walks back over to his desk and sits down. He opens his paper. Skinhead walks over to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: Dad? I haven't said this ina long time, and I might not say it again, but I love your boring old ass. The guard looks at him. Manages a smile. Skinhead holds out his hand. The guard looks at it. Skinhead wiggles his fingers. The guard sighs and holds out his hand. He wiggles his fingers and, at the same time as Skinhead, jerks his thumb back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
